data.title: VSCode Insiders adds import statements above file header comment
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.17.0-insider
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new .ts file: `a.ts`.
2. Add this code to `a.ts`:
    ```typescript
    export function a() {}
    ```
3. Save `a.ts`.
4. Create a new .ts file: `b.ts`.
5. Add a file header comment, e.g.:
    ```typescript
    /**
     * File: b.ts
     */
    ```
6. Below the file header comment, add:
    ```typescript
    const b = a()
    ```
7. Move cursor between `a` and `(`.
8. Press `CTRL+.`.
9. Choose _Import from "a"._

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

IMHO, the import statements should be place _below_ the file header comment.

data.title: Markdown is broken when read from GitHub viewer
data.body:

I suspect that there is an invisible character on VS Code different to the GitHub one when I click "space bar" between the hashtags and header title. (https://github.com/jorge-sanz/JUnitExample/commit/186ad2450abcec89ec4368b57a77e8f3eebc8ce9)

- OS Version: macOS High Sierra

data.title: Trashcan button kills entire terminal process tree including non-console apps
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (7ac1f1e05baad03d4dd8f8515f1e598180b2c97e, 2017-09-30T05:06:21.234Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a non-console app from vscode terminal (e.g. notepad)
2. Kill the terminal using the trashcan button

Expected: Only the terminal process and any other processes attached to the console should be killed.
Actual: Entire process tree is killed, even non-console applications.

data.title: clean up icon path confusion
data.body: With https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/269ae60a4b7f0afb4d779433d88d9c1ef2190bc6 the concept of an `iconPath` has been added. This competes with `iconClass` and having both doesn't make much sense. While I understand the reasoning for us having it `iconPath` is only honoured in a single place and every other user will fail to make it work. At least the `MenuItemActionItem` should know what to do, ideally no competing concepts exist.

data.title: debt - replace ExplorerViewerActionContributor with menu-registration
data.body: There is a lot of [code to register](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/search/browser/search.contribution.ts#L169) the "find in folder" action. Since a while we have `MenuId`s and menu registrations based on that. Find a sample in every caller of `MenuRegistry.appendMenuItem` like [this one](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/codeEditor/electron-browser/toggleWordWrap.ts#L253). The context key you are looking for is `explorerResourceIsFolder` to know if you are on a folder and `resource` to get the active resource

data.title: IntelliSense fails for absolute import paths
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0
- OS Version: Win10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. import module: `let Customer = require.main.require("./src/Models/Customer");`
2. use it: `let customer = new Customer();`

This syntax imports modules from the app's root, which avoids the problem of crazy paths like `"../../../../foo/bar/baz/Customer"`. But there is no intellisense for anything in the `Customer` module.

I've tried importing it directly as above, and also via a directory `index.js` file. Neither approach works.

I found this [related issue](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19342) which said I should have a `jsonconfig.json` with `"module": "es6"` and `"target": "ES6"`, but that doesn't help.

data.title: Renaming a symbol in a file shared by two projects only affects the files in one
data.body:
If you open two typescript projects sharing a common file with a symlink, and then do a "Rename Symbol" in the shared file, ONLY the files in the project were you did the operation  will be affected by the rename, rendering the other project files inconsistent. Steps to reproduce:

1- Create `/tmp/a` and `/tmp/b` projects and `/tmp/c` shared directory

```
cd /tmp ; mkdir a b c
cd a ; npm init ; tsc --init
ln -s ../c c
cd ..
cd b ; npm init ; tsc --init
ln -s ../c c
```

2- Create files:

```ts
/* /tmp/c/fc.ts */
export const C = 8

/* /tmp/a/a.ts */
import {C} from "./c/fc"
console.log(C)

/* /tmp/b/b.ts */
import {C} from "./c/fc"
console.log(C)
```

3- Now open both folders `a` and `b` in VS Code, then open `a/c/fc.ts` and do a "Rename symbol" on `C`. Only the files at the `a` folder will be affected. In the `b` project `fc.ts` will remain unchanged until you save it in the `a` project, then it will show the changes but it will not notice is a symbol change, so the `b` files will not be updated with the new symbol.

- VSCode Version: 1.16.1 27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d
- OS Version: Ubuntu 17.04

data.title: ExtensionContext.globalState strangeness

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I'm seeing a very strange issue with a couple of GitLens users (I have one user with the issue right now and we have tried to debug it). What looks like is happening is that the `globalState` that I set in GitLens is somehow being either cleared or set to a previous value on every restart of vscode.

For example, I use `context.globalState.get<string>('gitlensVersion')` to detect upgrades which I log to the output channel. In this user's case,  when it gets logged out it seems to have a value of `5.1.1-beta`, but when we look in the local storage -- that global gitlens key has a value of `5.3.0`, and if we restart vscode, we see exactly the same thing, it gets read/logged as `5.1.1-beta`, but we see it as `5.3.0` in local storage. We've pulled down the gitlens repo and tried to catch this in the debugger, but when in the debugger we never see the wrong value -- it always gets correctly read as `5.3.0`. I will also say if other keys get written to the same `globalState` -- we can see them properly in the local storage, but once we restart vscode they all disappear.

FYI, this user did have the marketplace version of GitLens installed on top of a previous beta vsix, but we removed all the versions and re-installed GitLens from scratch and still the behavior persists.

This users was on Linux, but I've had another case of almost the same behavior on macOS (https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/issues/130)

data.title: PowerShell ext and VMware.PowerCLI vis mount name is already in use
data.body:
## Details
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.2.9200
- Extensions: 

## Extensions
Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.3.2
ansible-vault|dho|0.0.9
python|don|0.7.0
ansible|haa|0.2.5
terraform|mau|0.0.18
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.3
vim|vsc|0.10.1
jinja|who|0.0.8
---

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Visual Studio Code
2. Install PowerShell Extension
3. Open any .ps1 file
4. Run the following commands within the integrated console:
```
Install-Module "VMware.PowerCLI"
Import-Module "VMware.PowerCLI"
```
## Exception
```
import-module : The specified mount name 'vis' is already in use.
At line:1 char:1
+ import-module vmware.powercli
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (:) [Import-Module], DriveException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NewDriveProviderException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ImportModuleCommand
```
But if i run `get-psprovider | Select-Object -ExpandProperty Drives` it's not listed.
Also running it from the normal console within Visual Studio Code, PowerShell or PowerShell ISE works whithout this problem.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No (Problem with PowerShell Extension "ms-vscode.powershell")

data.title: $tsc problemmatcher fails with long output lines in terminal window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-file-peek|abi|1.0.1
jenkins-status|ale|0.4.0
githistory|don|0.2.3
vscode-generate-getter-setter|DSK|0.4.2
gitlens|eam|5.4.0
tslint|eg2|1.0.9
vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.1
vscode-great-icons|emm|2.1.16
status-bar-tasks|Gua|0.2.1
vscode-firefox-debug|hbe|0.16.0
debugger-for-phantomjs|ira|0.1.1
docthis|joe|0.4.8
typelens|kis|1.5.0
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.3.1
vscode-docker|Pet|0.0.18
java|red|0.10.0
html-less-class-completion|wan|0.0.6



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a dummy task in gruntFile.js to print a long string in the format for some valid typescript error
2. Configure this dummy grunt task as your build task with problem-matcher $tsc
3. 'Build' your project (thus causing the dummy grunt task to run and use integrated terminal window)
4. Notice that for long line outputs, integrated terminal splits it into multiple lines (even when actual output is single line)
5. The $tsc problem matcher treats each line as independent and hence fails to properly report the error in problems tab

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No Yes

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6870404/31071040-37a0e14e-a780-11e7-8186-1433f5192f8b.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6870404/31071059-4595604a-a780-11e7-8039-1bdf9d4f0550.png)

data.title: yum update error
data.body:
I have been trying to update Code 1.16.0 from the yum repo for a few days now.  Everytime it tries it says "No Presto metadata available for code", starts the download which is very slow sometimes even though all other network activity is fine and then errors with "https://packages.microsoft.com/yumrepos/vscode/code-1.16.1-1505406659.el7.x86_64.rpm: [Errno -1] Package does not match intended download. Suggestion: run yum --enablerepo=code clean metadata".

I have tried cleaning the repo as suggested but the result is always the same.  I can just uninstall and grab the rpm itself but I do like the ability to just update from yum, it has been very slick until now.

I am on Centos 7 64 bit.

If you need any firther info just ask.

Thanks

Colin

data.title: VSCode hangs or freezes also with newer version

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T17:16:27.618Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-93-generic (Ubuntu 16.04 LTS)
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
docthis|joe|0.4.8



---

Steps to Reproduce:

Use vscode long time like two days and let it running over night.
I cannot say exact pattern what to do to repeat freeze.
I am editing .js file which contains es2017 javascript code
Freezing happens after many hours of editing.
Freezing have happened know 4 times.
If I remember correctly freezing happens when I switch back from other program.
I was not doing anything special just editing file.
During freeze I cannot move cursor with cursor key.
If I click with mouse, the cursor is not moved to point where I click.
I have many files open.
Tabs for 7 files are visible.
If I click tab, then file name is updated in same area where menu is located.
However tab do not change to that one I click.
I can click menu and then menu dropdown appears.
If select action like Command Palette nothing happens.
This is so for almost all menu items.
One exception is Help About. It shows information of visual studio code version.
Second exception is Help Report issues is also working.
If I click x to close VSCode application, that works.

This same thing happened earlier with VSCode 1.14.2
There is closed issue #33149 about this.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Not tested

data.title: Use local gulp in CI
data.body:
We already install `gulp` in `node_modules`, installing it again globally takes ~17s on every build.
It also means that we currently always use the latest version of Gulp (if Gulp 4 came out tomorrow, CI would break). This always uses the same version in package.json / npm-shrinkwrap.json. 

All the shell scripts already reference `gulp` and `mocha` from node_modules, so no changes needed there.
